children.subject: These are all good suggestions.  CS+X is still in play.  Conversations are still occurring with many potential partners including MCB and the Center for Computational Biology.  Nothing is certain as to which possibilities will become new majors yet.

@Michael-David Sasson

Was there a post where "CS+X" was discussed -- I never heard of this term.
He's referring to joint majors, like the ones listed at http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/majors-minors/joint-majors: a major that is CS+X, where X is something else.

BioE 131 is computational biology, though much more on the bio side than CS. It doesn't really cover anything with human systems and such though.

CS 176 is the CS computational biology, though it's much more on the CS side. From what I've heard, it's basically 170 applied to bio word problems.

I would look into some genetics courses in MCB/IB/plant-microbio

history.content:
Nicole linked this about a year ago: https://d1b10bmlvqabco.cloudfront.net/attach/hyq0br1u3kx7dg/icdxydvnk125h8/imm8fox9dtwb/Compbio_handout.pdf.

-----------------------------------

MCB major/CS minor here! I can provide a bit more info on the relevant MCB classes.

MCB 140 (General Genetics) - To build a better understanding of human genetics, you can't do better than this class. Along with teaching basic concepts in genomics, evolutionary genetics, and developmental genetics, this class covers current experimental techniques (RNASeq, ChIP-Seq, etc) that generate the large datasets you'd be working with in computational genetics (which is incredibly useful background knowledge to have).

MCB C100A (Biophysical Chemistry) - After genetics, I think this is the second most useful class. It covers thermodynamic/kinetic concepts related to protein, DNA, and RNA structure/function. This doesn't sound directly related to genetics, but I've lost track of the number of times this class has felt relevant in my computational genomics research. Part of this is because understanding the impact of a genetic mutation requires some understanding of what the mutation might do to the relevant protein. (Side note: it goes without saying this would be incredibly useful if you're interested in computational modeling of proteins for drug design, a la DE Shaw.)

Both classes require some basic biology background. If you haven't taken AP Bio or Bio 1A at Berkeley, I'd brush up on your biology knowledge before jumping into either class (how chromosomes are inherited, the central dogma of molecular biology, etc - nothing too intense). MCB C100A requires some basic chemistry knowledge as well, so again, if you haven't taken AP Chem or Chem 1A at Berkeley, I'd brush up on your chemistry knowledge.
Nicole linked this about a year ago: https://d1b10bmlvqabco.cloudfront.net/attach/hyq0br1u3kx7dg/icdxydvnk125h8/imm8fox9dtwb/Compbio_handout.pdf.

children.subject:
Sweet, I'm Public Health and CS and it's good to see there are some other combos out there that are interested in sorta the same stuff. What I've realized is that when I'm looking at some sort of PH and CS intersection, is that it almost invariably turns into applied Data Science, so I would recommend (depending on your year), doing work in some DS courses (8, 100, Prob 140, 189, etc).

Beyond that, some courses that I've found to be pretty great on the PH side of things are PH 150A (Epidemiology) which is basically understanding how to apply stats to talk about diseases in populations. Great class. 

I'm also really enjoying some Public Health graduate stats courses (PH245, PH241) which are basically centered around applying statistical methods (thankfully using a programming language) to PH datasets and deriving some intuition about what's going on. Ideally, I'll also be sticking around to take more during a 1 year masters in 2018-2019. 

If you're interested in Genetics at all, a good place to start is 150A followed by classes with Lisa Barcellos (http://sph.berkeley.edu/lisa-barcellos). She's one of the world experts in this field. Prof Marshall also seemed to be super cool and I really wanted to (though never got to) take classes with him as well (http://sph.berkeley.edu/john-marshall). 

Finally, if you're interested in doing *research* in this sort of thing, I'm part of a lab where I get to exercise both my PH and CS skills and it's been great. I know people with the kind of CS/Bio intersection are always in high demand in labs like mine so if you're interested in that sort of thing, hmu (it's also paid).

history.content:
Hi there!
I'm a CS major really interested in the intersection of computer science and biology (like bioinformatics, genomics, cancer detection, etc). Any recommendations on some good courses related to the biotech/bioinformatics field, especially to build some understanding of human systems and biology. Also, I remember in 61B, there was discussion of "CS+X" majors. Is that still happening? Thanks!
history.subject: Suggested Bio courses for interested CS students?
